title: Nightclub survivor recalls 'total chaos' of ceiling collapse that killed 221
summary_extractive: Carwin says he then repeatedly went out of the building, where he'd try to call paramedics, then return inside to shout his friend's name and call her phone. At 01:00 on Tuesday morning Carwin Javier Molleja was dancing with his mother in Santo Domingo's Jet Set nightclub when he noticed something fall from the ceiling. 'What I have in my head are the screams, the loud sound of the ceiling falling in, my mum's screams asking me if I'm OK, me asking her if she's OK,' Carwin recalls. Both Carwin and his mother, who had been standing near the stage, were struck on the head by pieces of falling ceiling, but were lucky to avoid serious injury. He says he wanted to continue trying to find his friend, but needed to take home his mother, who was in pain.
summary_abstractive: Carwin Javier Molleja was dancing with his mother in Santo Domingo's Jet Set nightclub when he noticed something fall from the ceiling. Both Carwin and his mother, who had been standing near the stage, were struck on the head by pieces of falling ceiling, but were lucky to avoid serious injury. Carwin says he remained at the scene for about an hour and a half after the collapse as 'total chaos'

title: General strike hits transport in Argentina
summary_extractive: It is the third general strike called by Argentina's powerful unions since President Javier Milei took office at the end of 2023. Milei has slashed subsidies for transport, fuel and energy, fired tens of thousands of public servants and closed government departments. Horacio Bianchi, a retired teacher living in Buenos Aires, told the Associated Press news agency people were suffering as they 'don't have enough money to eat'. The protest action comes as the Argentine government awaits whether it will be granted a new $20bn (15.4bn) loan from the International Monetary Fund. All domestic flights have been cancelled, while trains and metro services have been suspended in Buenos Aires and other parts of the country.
summary_abstractive: All domestic flights have been cancelled, while trains and metro services have been suspended in Buenos Aires and other parts of the country. Many shops remained closed in the capital but bus drivers continued to work. It is the third general strike called by Argentina's powerful unions since President Javier Milei took office in 2023.

title: British man's tattoo wrongly linked to Venezuelan gang in US government document
summary_extractive: A tattoo belonging to a man from Derbyshire has appeared in a US government document used to identify members of a notorious Venezuelan gang - despite the man having no connection to the group. Pete Belton, 44, from Ilkeston says he was shocked to find his forearm featured in a Department of Homeland Security (DHS) document used to help identify alleged members of Tren de Aragua (TdA), a transnational criminal organisation. One of them led BBC Verify to an Instagram post by a Nottingham-based tattoo artist who posted about Mr Belton's tattoo nearly a decade ago. Mr Belton's tattoo - a clock face with the date and time of his daughter's birth - was included in a set of nine images for 'detecting and identifying' TdA members. The same image of Mr Belton's tattoo also appeared in a September 2024 reportby the Texas Department of Public Safety(DPS) about TdA activity.
summary_abstractive: Pete Belton, 44, from Ilkeston, Derbyshire, has a clock face tattoo. It appeared in a document used to identify alleged members of Tren de Aragua (TdA), a transnational criminal organisation. Mr Belton says he has no connection to the gang and is worried about being linked to it. The Trump administration has already deported hundreds of alleged gang members to a high-security jail in El Salvador.

title: Girl, 17, whose dad is lost in nightclub rubble spends birthday at scene
summary_extractive: Shailyn told me her cousin was one of the rescue workers, sifting through the debris for her own uncle, which she said brought her peace of mind that a relative was inside doing everything in her power to try to track Mximo down. But by Wednesday evening, officials said that given the conditions at the site observed by the more than 300 rescue workers, they would conclude the rescue phase of their operations 'within hours'. The owner of the Jet Set nightclub, Antonio Espaillat, delivered a video message via social media expressing his condolences and those of 'all the Jet Set family', to the victims' relatives. Hours later, the government released a statement saying that 'all reasonable chances of finding more survivors have been exhausted' and so the search and rescue mission would give way to the recovery of bodies. Behind her as she spoke to me on Wednesday afternoon, a team of rescue workers was meticulously going through the rubble inside the building, listening for the slightest sound of a survivor beneath them.
summary_abstractive: Mximo Pea had been coming to the Jet Set nightclub every single Monday for the past 30 years. This week, excited to see a concert by the popular Dominican singer Rubby Prez, he took his wife and his sister. Now all three are buried beneath the rubble of the collapsed discotheque, after the roof caved in part way through the performance.

title: Despair as death toll from Dominican Republic nightclub collapse rises
summary_extractive: The first call the 41-year-old governor of Monte Cristi province placed as she lay injured in the debris was to President Luis Abinader, asking him to send the emergency services to save those around her who were also severely injured. At least 124 people died and more than 150 were injured in the incident, which happened just before 01:00 local time (05:00 GMT) on Tuesday at the Jet Set club, officials said. But around 17:00 local time, more than 16 hours after the tragedy had occurred, Zulinka was informed by rescue workers at the scene that her father had died before they could free him. Nelsy Cruz also survived the initial impact from the falling debris and was among the first to raise the alarm - by directly calling the president of the Dominican Republic. It was only after she had made the call to the president that Nelsy Cruz called her brother, seven-time Major League Baseball All-Star Nelson Cruz, their father said.
summary_abstractive: At least 124 people died and more than 150 were injured in the incident. Hundreds of guests were attending a concert by merengue singer Rubby Prez. Prez, as well as former Major League Baseball players Octavio Dotel and Tony Blanco, and a provincial governor are among those who have been confirmed dead. Mobile phone footage shows Prez on stage singing while the man recording can be heard talking.

title: Tracking the world's major cocaine route to Europe - and why it's growing
summary_extractive: Gangs use three main methods to smuggle cocaine into shipments: hiding drugs in cargo before it reaches the port, breaking into containers at the port, or attaching drugs to ships at sea. The Albanian mafia has expanded its presence in Ecuador in recent years, drawn by key trafficking routes through the country, and it now controls much of the cocaine flow from South America to Europe. After cocaine arrives in Ecuador from Colombia or Peru it is stashed in warehouses until his Albanian employers become aware of a shipping container that will be leaving one of the ports for Europe. Police say they seized a record amount of illicit drugs last year, the majority of it cocaine, and that this indicates total exports are on the rise. Despite Ecuador not producing the drug, 70% of the world's cocaine now flows through its ports, Ecuadorean President Daniel Noboa says.

title: Dominican Republic nightclub collapse kills 113
summary_extractive: Video footage apparently taken inside the club shows people sitting at tables in front of the stage and some dancing to the music in the back while Rubby Prez sings. At least 113 people have been killed and more than 150 injured after a roof collapsed at a nightclub in the Dominican Republic's capital Santo Domingo, officials have said. The incident happened in the early hours of Tuesday at a concert by popular merengue singer Rubby Prez at the Jet Set nightclub. In a separate mobile phone recording shared on social media, a man standing next to the stage can be heard saying 'something fell from the ceiling', while his finger can be seen pointing towards the roof. Dotel meanwhile began playing for the New York Mets in 1999 and played for teams including the Houston Astros, Oakland A's, New York Yankees, Chicago White Sox and Detroit Tigers until 2013.
summary_abstractive: At least 113 people have been killed and more than 150 injured. A provincial governor and former Major League Baseball pitcher Octavio Dotel were among the victims. The incident happened at a concert by popular merengue singer Rubby Prez. Hundreds of people were inside the venue and some 400 rescuers are still searching for survivors.

title: Royal Society of Biology mourns murdered scientist
summary_extractive: Mr Coatti, who took a master's course at University College London (UCL), worked for the RSB for eight years as science policy officer before being promoted to senior science policy officer. 'He was a passionate and dedicated scientist, leading RSB animal science work, writing numerous submissions, organising events and giving evidence in the House of Commons,' the RSB said. Santa Marta is a gateway to some of Colombia's most popular tourist destinations including Tayrona National Park, Minca and the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta mountains. Santa Marta's Mayor, Carlos Pinedo Cuello, said a reward of 50,000,000 Colombian pesos (8,940) was being offered for information leading to the capture of those responsible for the death of the Italian citizen. A hotel worker who spoke to Colombian newspaper El Tiempo said Mr Coatti had inquired about visiting the village of Minca and was conducting research on local animal species.
summary_abstractive: Alessandro Coatti's remains were discovered on the outskirts of Santa Marta. He had worked for the Royal Society of Biology for eight years. A reward of 50,000,000 Colombian pesos (8,940) is being offered for information.

title: Ashley Cain's 'shocking' experience in the Brazilian favelas
summary_extractive: The main thing Cain says he took away from speaking to these young men was to be there to listen to his sons and to 'lead by example [to] be the kind of man that I would enjoy to see my sons being'. He remembers meeting one man running a music enterprise, trying to get young men out of gangs by providing them opportunities to DJ and 'teaching them skills to allow them to live a much more prosperous and safer life'. People are losing their lives every single day,' says Cain about the impact of crime in some of the world's most hostile environments. Ashley Cain visited dangerous places around the world - and tried to understand why some young men choose a life of crime. Cain shares his shock walking into one favela and seeing people openly selling drugs or walking around with guns 'like it was normal'.
summary_abstractive: Ashley Cain spoke to young men involved in criminality around the world. He visited favelas in Brazil, gangs in Sweden and illegal gold mining in Colombia. He wanted to understand why they had chosen a life of crime and its impact on people.
